pages:
ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK TAR:OTH 37120 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
 
 
FOR  
 
 
ASSESSING PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT OUTCOMES 
 
IN PROJECTS 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
November 2003

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  CSP  –  country strategy program 
  IFI  –  international financial institution 
  PSA  –  private sector assessment 
  PSD  –  private sector development 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
       
       
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by K. Decker (team leader), R. Simpson, B. Finlayson, W. Wicklein, V. 
John, G. Settle, and L. Kalver.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Developing a strong and dynamic private sector is vital for long-term economic growth, a 
necessary precondition for poverty reduction. Private sector development (PSD) is among the 
key objectives on the development agendas of many developing member countries (DMCs). 
DMCs implementing PSD initiatives carry out policies, programs, and projects in support of 
PSD, often assisted by international financial institutions (IFIs) and aid agencies to attract 
private sector investment. The results of these initiatives, however, are mixed. Private investors 
continue to perceive several DMCs as high risk, claiming that progress on the PSD agenda in 
terms of creating more conducive enabling conditions and a business environment in which the 
private sector can flourish falls below expectations.1 Faced with private sector reluctance to get 
involved or expand, DMCs understand the need to expedite the implementation of their PSD 
agendas and are becoming increasingly concerned about increasing the PSD impacts that their 
projects may achieve.  
 
2.  In  response  to  this  concern  and  to  enhance  the  capacity  of  DMCs  and  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  increase  transparency  in  terms  of  PSD  impact  orientation  of 
projects at the outset, this regional technical assistance (TA) will develop, test, and implement a 
set of tools for facilitating greater focus on PSD on the project level and for assessing PSD 
impacts of public sector operations and the development impacts of private sector operations in 
DMCs by using ADB projects as examples. Building DMC capacity to use these tools will enable 
them to better plan for, use, and manage their PSD initiatives and will thus directly link into 
future country strategies and programs.2 This is in line with ADB’s PSD strategy3 in which ADB 
commits  to  institutionalizing  the  PSD/development  impacts  of  projects  to  enhance  their 
development effectiveness. The concept of this TA was approved by ADB’s regional technical 
assistance  screening  committee  in  April  20034  and  was  endorsed  by  the  PSD  steering 
committee as a priority. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  PSD  cuts  across  a  large  number  of  factors,  sectors,  and  actors, and  results  often 
become  visible  only  in  the  medium  to  long  term.  To  show  successful  results  requires 
comprehensive  coordination,  continuing  review  and  analysis,  and  perceptive  monitoring. 
Economic and social indicators have been established, refined, evaluated, and reconfigured to 
approximate  the  status  of  PSD  in  a  country.  Most  of  these  indicators  are  on  the  macro-
economic or sector level and do not lend themselves to an assessment in advance of how 
specific DMC projects can contribute to specific PSD/development impacts in that country.  
 
4.  To monitor the contribution of projects in advancing the PSD agenda in DMCs, ADB’s 
PSD strategy requires tracking ADB’s portfolio for progress achieved in enhancing the PSD 
impacts of public sector operations and development impacts of private sector operations in 
DMCs.5 It lists potential PSD impacts of projects in general terms, but does not provide a 
methodology for scoring and assessing their impact. In the absence of such scoring and related 
performance  indicators  and  benchmarks,  it  is  difficult  for  DMCs  and  ADB  to  compare  the 
                                                 
1  See ADB’s private sector assessments and ADB/WB investment climate studies for details. 
2  In this sense, this RETA is an extension of ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Supporting Country-Driven Private 
Sector Development Strategies. Manila (RETA 6082). 
3  ADB. 2000. Private Sector Development Strategy. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 3 June 2003. 
5 From here onwards the PSD impacts of public sector operations and development impacts of private sector  
operations will be replaced by PSD/development impacts.

2  
PSD/development intensity of projects or to tell whether a project is designed to have high, 
medium, or low PSD/development impact.6 This TA will develop a set of tools and build the 
capacity to use them, which will allow DMCs and ADB to make a comparable assessment of 
PSD/development impacts in projects. 
 
5.  The tools to be developed under the TA have to be applicable to different project 
modalities,  including  programs,  stand-alone  projects  (loans,  equity,  and  guarantees),  and 
technical  assistance.  They  must  achieve  a  balance  in  being  user-friendly  and  sufficiently 
standardized to allow for comparison of operations over time and across DMCs, yet must be 
flexible and comprehensive enough to determine project-specific PSD/development impacts in a 
specific country setup. In light of externalities and often only long-term effects, demonstrating 
causality between project and PSD/development impact and establishing a serial correlation 
between  them  will  be  a  challenge.  Where  PSD/development  results  cannot  be  quantified, 
qualitative criteria will be required.  
 
6.  The  tools  to  be  developed  will  be  based  on  existing  work  on  assessing 
PSD/development impacts to date7 and will include a PSD/development checklist to assist  in 
focusing on PSD/development impact during project preparation, a set of PSD criteria that will 
help determine whether a project covers PSD, a PSD/development scorecard that represents 
desirable PSD/development impacts and establishes the causal link between a project and 
related  PSD/development  impacts,  and  PSD/development  performance  indicators  and 
benchmarks that allow for measuring and analyzing concrete PSD/development impacts in 
advance as well as later on. The PSD/development scorecard and performance indicators and 
benchmarks will be both analytical and strategic tools and will direct and align future project 
development efforts by communicating strategic objectives.  
 
7.  An  important  factor  for  the  strategic  meaningfulness  of  the  PSD  scorecard  and 
performance indicators and benchmarks is the identification of desirable PSD/development 
impacts in a given country. ADB has been carrying out in many of its DMCs private sector 
assessments (PSAs) that provide information on the status of PSD for determining desirable 
PSD impacts. Based on this information and on the sector road maps developed by ADB as 
inputs  for  country  strategy  programs  (CSPs),  impacts  to  be  achieved  and  performance 
benchmarks can be developed. As a strategic instrument, the PSD/development scorecard will 
assign  a  priority  ranking  to  impacts  and  include  performance  targets  or  benchmarks  as 
indicators. A combination of before and after assessment on this basis can provide DMCs with 
concrete lessons learned. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The purpose of the TA is to assess PSD/development impacts of projects. The results of 
measurement can provide important lessons learned that may be applied in developing future 
projects. The goal of the TA is to enhance the capacity of DMCs and ADB to identify and 
measure the qualitative and quantitative aspects of PSD/development impacts in projects, thus 
making them more transparent.  
                                                 
6 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is assessing project impact in terms of transition from 
command to market economy.  
7  For  example,  work  by  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development  on  transition  impact,  and  by 
International Finance Corporation on additionality.

3 
 
9.  The activities of the TA aim to increase the focus on PSD/development impacts in 
projects.  TA  outputs  will  include  PSD  criteria,  PSD  checklists,  PSD  scorecards,  and 
performance  indicators  and  benchmarks.  The  TA  will  build  the  capacity  to  use  the  tools 
developed and lessons learned by disseminating the findings of the study to DMCs and ADB 
staff. Knowledge gained will be used to improve the design and implementation of ADB projects 
in DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will build on ADB’s PSD strategy and its strategic thrusts, PSAs, sector road 
maps, and CSPs and will consist of four activity clusters: (i) selection of pilot-test projects, (ii) 
research and analysis, (iii) development and testing of outputs, and (iv) capacity building and 
dissemination.  
 
11.  The implementation of the TA will begin with activity cluster (i), with staff discussions in 
headquarters, particularly in regional departments and Operations Evaluation Department, on a 
long list of projects for the pilot test. Sectors to be covered include infrastructure (power and 
energy, transport, and telecommunications), finance (banking and capital markets), small and 
medium-size enterprises, trade, agriculture, natural resources, and social sectors (water and 
sanitation, education, health). Selected thematic projects in poverty reduction, economic growth, 
governance, human development, regional cooperation, and gender will be included. The pilot 
test will focus on projects under preparation or in the early stages of implementation. Based on 
a detailed review of project documents and background information, the sectors and themes 
may be narrowed down and the long list reduced to a shortlist, with at least three projects in 
each of the selected sectors and thematic areas. Up to five DMCs, possibly one from each of 
ADB’s regions, will participate in the TA. The actual DMCs have not yet been identified but their 
selection will depend on the location of the short-listed projects and DMC interest in adopting 
PSD impact measures. Letters of no objection will be obtained before the initiation of the TA 
there, once the selection process is finalized during implementation. 
 
12.  In preparing to develop the PSD/development scorecard and performance benchmarks, 
key activities under activity cluster (ii) will include data collection, research and analysis of 
existing  PSD/development  benchmarks  and  indicators;  detailed  analysis  of  gaps  in  linking 
PSD/development  impacts  to  projects;  PSD/development  scorecard  and  performance 
benchmarks  or  indicator  proxies  of  other  IFIs  and  bilateral  funding  agencies;  review  and 
analysis of PSD/development impacts in ADB’s PSD strategy, PSAs, sector road maps, and 
CSPs; and research and analysis of PSD/development impacts in ADB projects.  
 
13.  Activity cluster (iii) will include the development of a set of tools will help identify and 
evaluate specific PSD/development impacts in projects. Building on ADB’s PSD strategy, the 
tools will include PSD criteria in ADB that provide an understanding of what is considered PSD 
and determine, before a project or after, whether it includes PSD aspects; PSD/development 
checklists for project development to assist government officials and project team leaders in 
focusing  on  PSD/development  impact;  PSD/development  scorecards  for  desired 
PSD/development impacts; and PSD/development performance benchmarks for measuring and 
analyzing concrete PSD/development impacts in advance as well as later on. TA outputs will 
include  guidelines  for  using  the  tools  developed  and  for  setting  targets  or  benchmarking 
PSD/development performance. The TA outputs will be pilot-tested in the short-listed projects. A 
crucial task under this activity cluster is to establish a broad consensus on the tools among

4  
DMCs and within ADB. Following the refinement and finalization of the TA outputs, they will be 
available for application to all ADB projects.  
                                                                                                                                                      
14.  Activity cluster (iv) consists of building capacity and consensus and dissemination. It 
entails national workshops and an interregional workshop to facilitate dialogue between DMCs 
and ADB staff as well as interregional exchange. DMCs from all regions will be invited to the 
workshop. The outputs and findings of the TA will be presented in the form of a handbook. In 
addition, a CD ROM will be prepared for training purposes, and web content on the TA for 
ADB’s web site will be developed for wider dissemination. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. Details of the cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. Staff from the Governance and Regional 
Cooperation  Division  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  will  be 
responsible for all TA activities. The PSD committee will serve as the advisory group to the TA 
and will generate the project long list, facilitate the generation of the shortlist, and review and 
comment on the consultants’ outputs. TA activities will be closely coordinated with regional 
departments,  the  Private  Sector  Operations  Department,  sector  and  thematic  committees, 
ongoing ADB activities, as well as activities of other IFIs and aid agencies. 
 
17.  It is estimated that consulting services of 17 person-months (12 international and 5 
domestic)  will  be  required.  ADB  will  engage  individual  consultants  in  accordance  with  its 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  for  engaging  domestic 
consultants. The international consultants will comprise two PSD specialists with extensive 
expertise and experience in public and private sector projects, sequencing PSD, development 
impacts in private sector operations, impact assessment, sector-wide approaches, creating 
conducive business environments, and managing business processes for measurable results. 
International consultants will be required to have extensive PSD and IFI project experience in 
Asia and the Pacific region. The domestic consultants will include one PSD specialist/research 
analyst per participating DMC to assist the international team and facilitate local workshops. The 
outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA is expected to start in April 2004 and to be implemented over 12 months, ending 
in April 2005. Implementation will include local and an interregional workshop for disseminating 
the  pilot-test  results  and  study  findings,  facilitating  interregional  exchange,  and  providing 
capacity building on the outputs developed. The consultants will submit an inception report 3 
weeks after the team leader’s input begins; brief monthly interim progress reports; a draft final 
report, including the manual on the use of the tools after 5.5 months of team leader’s inputs; a 
draft report of the proceedings of the interregional workshop 1 week after the workshop; and a 
final report by the end of the TA period. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for

5 
Assessing Private Sector Development Outcomes in Projects, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
A.  International Consultants (12 person-months) 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented over a period of 12 months. The 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit two international private sector development (PSD) 
specialists as consultants, with one of them acting as team leader. The consultants will work 
closely together and provide 12 person-months of consulting services. They will have generally 
similar terms of reference, as described in the following paragraphs, with the team leader taking 
on the additional tasks of preparing a work program and having accountability of leadership, 
liaison with ADB, and reporting. 
 
2.  The  consultants  should  have  an  advanced  degree  in  economics,  business 
administration,  law,  or  a  related  discipline;  and  proven  knowledge  and  extensive  work 
experience in PSD, ideally on project development and on project evaluation, and in public and 
in private sector projects. They should have worked extensively with or within international 
financial  institutions  (IFIs).  They  will  be  experts  on  issues  such  as  sequencing  of  PSD; 
development  impacts  in  private  sector  operations;  PSD  impact  assessment;  sectorwide 
approaches; creating conducive business environments; and managing business processes for 
measurable  outputs,  outcomes,  and  impacts.  The  consultants  should  have  extensive 
experience in Asia and the Pacific region and expertise in different sectors so that they can 
complement each other.  
  
3.  The consulting tasks will include, but will not be limited, to four general areas. 
1.  Selection of Pilot-Test Projects 
4.  The specific tasks of the consultants include to: 
(i)  Carry out a detailed review of project documents and other available 
background information for projects on the long list.  
 
(ii)  Work  with  sector  and  thematic  committees,  ADB  staff  in  regional 
departments, Operations Evaluation Department, and the PSD committee 
in  identifying  selection  criteria  for  short  listing  and  assist  in  selecting 
projects and developing member countries (DMCs) for the shortlist. 
 
2.  Data Collection, Research and Analysis  
5.  The consultants’ tasks in this area follow: 
 
(i)  Conduct a desk review of PSD-related policies; strategies; assessments; 
frameworks; plans; sector road maps; country strategy programs/updates; 
and other relevant documents of governments, ADB, other IFIs or aid 
agencies for the participating DMCs; and the sectors and themes covered 
by the project shortlist. Analyze PSD objectives, outputs, outcomes, and 
impacts.  
 
(ii)  Based  on  the  analysis  in  (i),  review,  compare,  and  analyze  PSD 
objectives,  outputs,  outcomes,  and  impacts  of  the  projects  on  the 
shortlist.

Appendix 3  9 
 
(iii)  Research  and  analyze  existing  PSD  performance  benchmarks  and 
indicators, provide a detailed analysis of the gap in linking PSD impacts of 
projects  to  them,  and  identify  how  this  analysis  can  be  used  for 
developing the outputs for the TA. 
 
(iv)  Research and analyze approaches and methodologies to identify and 
assess PSD impacts of other IFIs and aid agencies for good practices 
and lessons learned and how these lessons can be used for developing 
the outputs for this TA. 
 
(v)  Refine  existing  definitions  of  PSD,  development  impact,  outputs, 
outcomes,  and  impacts  for  the  purposes  of  the  TA  and  compile  the 
findings of the research and analysis. 
 
3.  Development and Pilot-Testing of Outputs  
6.  Consultants’ tasks included in this area follow: 
 
(i)  Building on the research and analysis above, develop a set of tools that 
allows  identification,  assessment,  and  optimization  of  specific 
PSD/development impacts before and after projects. Identify alternative 
approaches and methodologies for each of the tools to be developed, 
explain  pros  and  cons  of  each  methodology,  and  recommend  the 
preferred option.  
 
(ii)  Explain the differences in outputs, outcomes, and impacts in assessing 
PSD/development impacts, including differentiating them in terms of the 
control over them of parties involved in a project; and account for external 
shocks in the assessment before as well as after the project. 
 
(iii)  Develop PSD/development criteria, possibly in the form of a flow chart 
that  gives  an  understanding  of  what  is  considered  PSD/development 
criteria  and  determines,  before  or  after,  whether  a  project  includes 
PSD/development impacts. 
 
(iv)  Develop  PSD/development  impact  checklists  that  assist  government 
officials and project team leaders in focusing project development on 
PSD/development impacts. 
 
(v)  Develop  PSD/development  impact  scorecards  for  desired 
PSD/development impacts as well as guidelines for a scoring system. 
 
(vi)  Develop  PSD/development  performance  indicators  for  measuring  and 
analyzing concrete PSD impacts before as well as after the project and 
develop guidelines for setting targets or benchmarks for the performance 
indicators.  
 
(vii)  Throughout the process of developing the outputs, liaise with DMCs and 
other IFIs; seek views and feedback from relevant regional departments,

10  Appendix 3 
sector, and thematic committees; and prepare a handbook on the use of 
the outputs, including related guidelines.  
 
(viii)  Pilot-test  the  outputs  on  the  short-listed  projects  and  make 
revisions/refinement as necessary.  
 
4.  Capacity Building and Dissemination 
7.  In this area, the consultants’ tasks include to: 
 
(i)  Design, conduct, and document a set of national workshops for building 
capacity  and  consensus  during  output  development  as  well  as  an 
interregional capacity building workshop on the outputs developed under 
the TA for governments, IFIs, aid agencies, and ADB staff and present 
and discuss the results of the pilot test.  
 
(ii)  Prepare a CD ROM on the use of the TA outputs for training purposes. 
 
(iii)  Develop web content on the TA for publication on ADB’s web site and 
wider dissemination. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (5 person-months)  
8.  In  each  participating  DMC,  one  domestic  PSD  specialist/research  analyst  will  be 
engaged for 1 person-month on an intermittent basis to support the international consultants. 
The specialists will have a degree in economics, business administration, or a related discipline; 
and  a  good  network  as  well  as  experience  in  working  on  PSD-related  initiatives  with  the 
government or the private sector. Responsibilities include acting as a link between officials of 
the participating governments and the international consultant, researching and responding to 
queries,  preparing  missions,  scheduling  meetings,  and  organizing  local  workshops.  After 
workshops and field visits of the international consultants, the domestic experts will prepare 
detailed minutes of proceedings and key issues emerging from the workshops and meetings, 
and may be required to follow up on issues as requested. In addition, one support staff will be 
hired in Manila for the TA.  
 
C.  Expected Results and Deliverables 
9.  Expected results and deliverables under the TA include PSD criteria, PSD checklists, 
PSD scorecards, PSD performance benchmarks and indicators, and an application manual with 
guidelines for setting performance targets; capacity and consensus building workshops; an 
implementation plan for PSD/development impact measurement; web content on the TA; a CD 
ROM for training purposes; and a publication. 
 
10.  The consultants will deliver an inception report, including a proposed work program, 3 
weeks  after  the  team  leader’s  input  begins;  brief  monthly  progress  reports  demonstrating 
progress in developing the outputs and addressing feedback received on previous reports; a 
draft final report, including a manual on the use of the tools after 5.5 months of team leader’s 
inputs;  a  draft  report  of  the  proceedings  of  the  interregional  workshop  1  week  after  the 
workshop; and a final report by the end of the TA period.

metadata.Title: Assessing Private Sector Development Outcomes in Projects
